#Text=CHAPTER XIV
#Text=The nearest way to the garden , on going out of my lady ’s sitting-room , was by the shrubbery path , which you already know of .
#Text=For the sake of your better understanding of what is now to come , I may add to this , that the shrubbery path was Mr. Franklin ’s favourite walk .
#Text=When he was out in the grounds , and when we failed to find him anywhere else , we generally found him here .
#Text=I am afraid I must own that I am rather an obstinate old man .
#Text=The more firmly Sergeant Cuff kept his thoughts shut up from me , the more firmly I persisted in trying to look in at them .
#Text=As we turned into the shrubbery path , I attempted to circumvent him in another way .
#Text=“ As things are now , ” I said , “ if I was in your place , I should be at my wits ’ end . ”

#Text=“ If you were in my place , ” answered the Sergeant , “ you would have formed an opinion — and , as things are now , any doubt you might previously have felt about your own conclusions would be completely set at rest .
#Text=Never mind for the present what those conclusions are , Mr. Betteredge .
#Text=I have n’t brought you out here to draw me like a badger ; I have brought you out here to ask for some information .
#Text=You might have given it to me no doubt , in the house , instead of out of it .
#Text=But doors and listeners have a knack of getting together ; and , in my line of life , we cultivate a healthy taste for the open air . ”
#Text=Who was to circumvent this man ?
#Text=I gave in — and waited as patiently as I could to hear what was coming next .

#Text=“ We wo n’t enter into your young lady ’s motives , ” the Sergeant went on ; “ we will only say it ’s a pity she declines to assist me , because , by so doing , she makes this investigation more difficult than it might otherwise have been .
#Text=We must now try to solve the mystery of the smear on the door — which , you may take my word for it , means the mystery of the Diamond also — in some other way .
#Text=I have decided to see the servants , and to search their thoughts and actions , Mr. Betteredge , instead of searching their wardrobes .
#Text=Before I begin , however , I want to ask you a question or two .
#Text=You are an observant man — did you notice anything strange in any of the servants ( making due allowance , of course , for fright and fluster ) , after the loss of the Diamond was found out ?
#Text=Any particular quarrel among them ?
#Text=Anyone of them not in his or her usual spirits ?
#Text=Unexpectedly out of temper , for instance ?
#Text=or unexpectedly taken ill ? ”

#Text=I had just time to think of Rosanna Spearman ’s sudden illness at yesterday ’s dinner — but not time to make any answer — when I saw Sergeant Cuff ’s eyes suddenly turn aside towards the shrubbery ; and I heard him say softly to himself , “ Hullo ! ”
#Text=“ What ’s the matter ? ” I asked .
#Text=“ A touch of the rheumatics in my back , ” said the Sergeant , in a loud voice , as if he wanted some third person to hear us .
#Text=“ We shall have a change in the weather before long . ”
#Text=A few steps further brought us to the corner of the house .
#Text=Turning off sharp to the right , we entered on the terrace , and went down , by the steps in the middle , into the garden below .
#Text=Sergeant Cuff stopped there , in the open space , where we could see round us on every side .
#Text=“ About that young person , Rosanna Spearman ? ” he said .
#Text=“ It is n’t very likely , with her personal appearance , that she has got a lover .
#Text=But , for the girl ’s own sake , I must ask you at once whether she has provided herself with a sweetheart , poor wretch , like the rest of them ? ”
#Text=What on earth did he mean , under present circumstances , by putting such a question to me as that ?
#Text=I stared at him , instead of answering him .
#Text=“ I saw Rosanna Spearman hiding in the shrubbery as we went by , ” said the Sergeant .
#Text=“ When you said ‘ Hullo ’ ? ”
#Text=“ Yes — when I said ‘ Hullo ! ’
#Text=If there ’s a sweetheart in the case , the hiding does n’t much matter .
#Text=If there is n’t — as things are in this house — the hiding is a highly suspicious circumstance , and it will be my painful duty to act on it accordingly . ”
#Text=What , in God ’s name , was I to say to him ?

#Text=I knew the shrubbery was Mr. Franklin ’s favourite walk ; I knew he would most likely turn that way when he came back from the station ; I knew that Penelope had over and over again caught her fellow-servant hanging about there , and had always declared to me that Rosanna ’s object was to attract Mr. Franklin ’s attention .
#Text=If my daughter was right , she might well have been lying in wait for Mr. Franklin ’s return when the Sergeant noticed her .

#Text=I was put between the two difficulties of mentioning Penelope ’s fanciful notion as if it was mine , or of leaving an unfortunate creature to suffer the consequences , the very serious consequences , of exciting the suspicion of Sergeant Cuff .

#Text=Out of pure pity for the girl — on my soul and my character , out of pure pity for the girl — I gave the Sergeant the necessary explanations , and told him that Rosanna had been mad enough to set her heart on Mr. Franklin Blake .
#Text=Sergeant Cuff never laughed .
#Text=On the few occasions when anything amused him , he curled up a little at the corners of the lips , nothing more .
#Text=He curled up now .
